newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish security council meets amid coalition rift.
newsitem.headline: Turkish security council meets amid coalition rift.

text.p: Turkey's powerful National Security Council began a meeting on Monday in the shadow of a coalition rift caused by a military demand to keep Islam out of public life.
Generals and civilian leaders entered the meeting at President Suleyman Demirel's official residence carrying thick files and briefcases, witnesses said.
Demands by the military-dominated council last month for measures against religious activism have exposed cracks in Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan's Islamist-led government.
A minister from the secular wing of the alliance was quoted on Monday as urging an end to the alliance.

"This government cannot find a solution to the tension in the country. A new, broad-based government must be formed without wasting any time," the Hurriyet daily quoted Trade and Industry Minister Yalim Erez as saying.
Erez and fellow members of the True Path Party government ally have become increasingly critical of what they see as Erbakan's reticence to implement the army's demands.

The generals want restrictions imposed on religious education, enforcement of a ban on Islamic dress and an assault on pro-Islamist media and business as part of a planned return to Turkey's rigid secularism of the 1920s.
Erbakan, modern Turkey's first Islamist leader, has agreed to the demands in principle but his government has yet to expedite any of them.
